msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M1-8. 2 of 8. Anon. Holograph. In [Articles, essays, fiction and reviews], vol. 8 [1938-39], pp. 78-102. 13p.

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

p.s: Anon died .. round about 1477. It was the printed book that killed him yet at fair, the printed book until then the song was

div.p: Then the house is built; & the some one – a clergyman; looks back. He looks back Time has drawn its blue veil over the horizon. He has time to think about the past in the quiet of the parsonage. He
Anon is singing
all Knigh

Then at When the house is built, Anon stops at the back door. He sings Upstairs they talk French; English has was gone down into the kitchen into the farmyard. He sings in an uncouth fou . . He sings to young men & maids. He tells them what they have heard already. But save for this voice the English might be a dumb race. & for the voice of & the English might be a dumb race; to

p.sup: the mummers & the jugglers, the minstrels & the actors

div.p: Then The pr Then about Anon is still the only [unparticular?] voice. But aft The house however became more & more comfortable. At last we see someone in the house winter is past. . . And the great E (Elizabethan) house is in existence.
The Printing Press had come. It is the Printing Press that preserves the dumb world.

Then when the house was built, & roads led often flooded, often deep in mud, led to from house to house came along the roads, came the minstrels, the jugglers, the singers, bear leaders, singing their crude songs at the back door, to the farm hands & the maid servants, in the uncouth jargon of the their native tongue English Upstairs they talked French
Icham for wore...

Upstairs they spoke French. The nature singer was man at the back door was despised. He [It?] had no name, no station yet even the Kings & Queens must have their singers, their actors. He was a jester, a [illeg.] Perhaps But even the Kings & Queens must have their minstrel, even if they despised him, they tolerated him, as we tolerate those who say out loud what we think, but will not admit. If he was had the outsiders privilege, to say the to mockup the irreverent, the to comment; to He too was the to see from the outside. He preserved to the old stories. He he As time went on, he He put into words the things that were remembered – the old legends; the old he dan incited the peasants to As time went on, & the there houses were grouped by the road, a church, he & the church found in the [midst?], he was to be found acting in the church; he a & then, when his as his acting became more & more definite as he acted himself a more & more secular past, he left the church, acted in the churchyard, & was at last admitted to the market place. But he was the scholars have nameless. His songs were unwritten
he was ribald, he was often obscene. It is

During the silent centuries, before the book was printed, his is the only voice that was to be heard in England. The He It was a Save for Save for Anon singing of his day in the back door, the English might be a desert race, a race of individuals nameless [priest?], who left behind them stone barns, cultivated fields, & great churches but no words.

It was the Yet, during all these centuries, as the scholars tell us, Anon was never silent also sang. He was It was he who gave voice to the old stories, who found the when he came to the back door incited the peasants to put off their wooly clothes & to dress themselves in green leaves, to take [illeg.] in their hands, to enact wh the old pagan beliefs which has still the [antiquaries?] had not created. If we cd. (could) see the village as it was before time we
shd. (should) see tracks across the fields leading from the main house to the farm, to the cottage, to the hovel. The paths were worn, often by the soldiers, & by the labourers. They scar [illeg.] by the & sow [by the?] of they were [illeg.] to be conquered by man, as by nature. That connection, as time goes on, is painfully & minutely recorded in old papers, old account books. It made the shape of the

But This [anonymous?] that the , which was so [even?] to kill , was the preserved him. There in the [21?] pass & we shd. (should) that we tap the cl [illeg.] of [writer?] put that lay deep [flush?] in the
The The legend was still fact when
The book printed book fixed in a [& for?] all the dream world that was about to fade under the [surface?] of the sixt El (Elizabethan)
Of the writer [nothing?] is known. is not distinct from his book. The book is still the voice of Anon speaking to the dreaming mind of Anon.

[dow?] his [loubell?] the end of that world, it is now written down, fixed; nothing will be added, even if the dream the legend survives. After that the the audience became separate & the After that, we have the individual; the man who looks back; who sees the past against the present.
There is in , the [parsonage?] in his [liking?]. He These old stories are to him [office?] [illeg.] born. They

the preacher, the man who went from town to town among the living peasants among among the peasants & the nobles, heard them & the sound & his fury. , riding in a [illeg.] homeward from "going to preach, in the church,
found the church door fast locked and one of the parish came to me & Lo this is a busy day with us, we cannot hear you, it is day. The parish are far abroad to gather for Robin hood,... I was fain there to give place to R H: I thought my [Racket?] wd. (would) have been regarded, tho' I was not; but it
wd (would) not serve, it was fain to give place to Robin hoods men. It was no laughing matter my friends, it is a weeping matter, a heavy matter, a heavy matter, ....

p.s: It is the preacher who shows us the living body of the living body the English peasant whose still honouring the pagan Gods: still honouring the old gods; still immersed in superstition. The preacher [imposes upon them his?] God. It is in the preacher who killed There is the voice that went up & down England Latimer as no chronicler of times past. To Latimer the old dreams games, the old [songs?] Latimer,

div.p: going up & down England, saw the peasant as he is now at this moment, in King reign in 1549. He saw the peasant still harbouring old superstitions, going on pilgrimage, setting up candles, worshipping [higs?] bones. The saw He saw the There was no beauty, it was but only superstition & corruption in their ancient games. He

saw the present moment in all its crudity. He saw the was no antiquary. He knew what he He had his His eyes were open as he rode from town to town to what was actually in existence. He saw poverty; he saw the peasant suff unable to buy a grave. He saw the nobles [eye?] long the field. He saw the great man lying [illeg.] to in bed, after his [hawking?] & his hunting, in the poor made waiting hour after hour to bring his care upon him. He saw the great ladies wearing vardigalls & puffing their hair out in tussocks. And what he saw in the roads, in the fields, in the house, he described in a voice that stumbles & stutters & cannot keep to the theme; for he is enraged by what he sees. This was the voice of the new learning. As he walked in the garden, looking in my [bokes?] – "I cannot go long [bokes?], for poor folks come unto me, desiring tha me that I will [illeg.] so that their matters may be heard If he tries to send in the A of C (Archbishop of Canterbury's) garden, the poor come knocking at the gate, & his man says "Lo there is someone at the gate wd (would) speak with you..." and so faithfully, [outpoured?] not [illeg.] he wd (would) he brings before the young king the state of England at the very moment.

To him the old Engand is no less It is the preacher who [exacts?] the farmers farmers; the for he fain upon them the light of the new knowledge. He alone knows what he is saying for he too, until he was thirty "walked in the shadow of death"
He too had, taken [illeg.] part in the old superstitions. But since But

It was master at who opened his eyes. Master Bilney who went about among the poor & the sick, & finally had a paper set in his hand & was burnt. So, it was he, he the [illeg.] will be burnt. Meanwhile he will speak the truth; he will speak in English. He will speak in a word that the poor, the [simple?] can understand, in their own tongue. It was the preacher then, saying the in to at the beg (beginning) & the end of his [sermons?] who put English into the highest places. But indeed while during all [minstrels?] & mummers, he was yet fashioning a language for them to use. He was giving a common tongue speech for nobles & peasants. But to He Just as Harrison comes Standing on the edge of the edge of the
Et (Elizabethan) age, he saw the [gorgeous?] buildings she and Harrison saw there. He deplored them Never has there been such building & planting" he saw. Never had there been such crime, such splendour, such poverty. "There never was such building then, as is now planting, nor marrying. The wealth that had come from the sale of the monasteries, was not given to Give the money that used to be shut in

There be none now but great mens rooms in colleges. It will come to pass that we shall have nothing but a little English divinity that will bring the realm into a very barbarousness, & utter decay of learning. Give the money "that it were wont to bestow in pilgrimage matters, in trentalls, in masses, in purgatory matters" to poor [illeg.] so that they may become scholars.

This is the voice that ousted superstition: the voice of reason, of common sense. By using English, by putting English in the pulpit the preacher was forging the very weapon that gave the old [methods?] a new lease of life.

Thus and both saw what we can still see, the great Elizabethan house sitting often on the ruins & foundation of the old. The sight & sound in both of them the same [illeg.]: Harrison [described?] the men, with him . . Latimer the women But We sti can see the house now, steady in its ... still silent. They cannot speak. They use the biblical prose. Old [Lacy tone?]

p.sup: the same house [today?] the house that built on the old foundations the gt (great) E (Elizabethan) house

div.p:
To , was a [illeg.] thief. He was He had walked in the shadow of death " till he was 30, but then his eyes were opened, & he was through the cloud of superstition that still obscured his thought He saw things as they were, he saw through the old popish through the old Popish preachers, the old pagan customs. He saw England still, at the moment in its reality. He was no antiquary. He did not dig in the garden for roman coins. When he walked in the A of C (Archbishop of Canterbury's) garden, a man his man came & said: "Sir there is one that wd. (would) speak with you." Then He shut his house, a heart He he said so "the cry of the washerman is come up
up to my ears "mine ears" The poor Labourers, Gun makers, Powdermen, Bow makers, Arrow makers, Smiths, Carpenters, [Solderers?], & other crafts
cry out..." 111 Then he [unpaid?]. So He laid aside his book. He found waited on the great man & found him still in bed. They the prelates they hawke He found the prelates,
They hawke, they hunt, they carde, they dice they patronise in the palaces with [gallows?] flatterers, with their dancing mummers, & with
their fresh companions... Standing up by the the King himself he laid bare the state of England. In a voice that starts & stammers repeating the word as in his hard [powder?] the [cake?], he [fight?] to the English [illeg.]

We cannot hear them talking: the sound of the noble is in these ears They speak ceremoniously lay sounding in that [imaginary?] still to the speech of the [bible?] There is no language [press?]. When Lady writes to she adminishes, she exhorts. She is a preacher advising a subordinate. She She Fear of god, fear of man shroud her with the walls of a dungeon. They are Again, we cannot hear the voices they heard- the voice of the [mummers?], of the [illeg.]. [But?] we can see the path that led to the well & the tree. It is an isolated house: a house full of finery, but & furniture; but in wh. (which) the Elhns (Elizabethans) set like painted images. less without [sit?] atmosphere, direction. There is no medium between the white & the scarlet, the glass & the gold.[Begat?] concentrated colour must on their faces; there is no mediium [carnale?], snow: ebony & gold. There is no natural medium [congregation?] The writer then must be a poet–– For when familiar letters are written in –

To [denegate?] the song from its encumberances becomes as time goes on a task for the critic – that specially qualified taster who was not yet in existence when emerged at last partially at least from the depths of anonymity.
But he had the past behind him. For why a For why a Gods name, he exclaimed may not we as else the Greeks, have the Kingdom of our own language?
So he was aware of his language, its possibilities, its
The writer must have the past behind him. For Spenser the golden age was of English was .

Behind him too is the Morte darthur the old world of the , the world is Kings ladies, dwarfs, giants. But he has ceased to believe in giants. Therefore they have gone If He no longer believes, [unlike?] noblemen in 1470 that King was a real man. Thus his poem lacks the reality of the Morte d'Arthur. It has not the He cannot see within as Malory saw the: When Malory sees sharply & distinctly, Spenser sees at a distance; he sees with [regret?], with [illeg.] desire; but not with belief. There is no sense of He cannot His figures are pass at a distance. They do not He cannot make us believe; he cannot There is no sharpness in the figures of the : no [vice?], no belief, no edge: no such closeness or comes none of that reality wh. (which) comes from the belief: On the other hand he shows us as Malory cannot, the world surrounded by [words?]. His vision is not fixed in the figure: but holds the more so that if we lose the

p.sup: Looking at them from a distance he sees them pictorally

div.p: He gives It holds the It holds the surrounding [illeg.]. He realises time & change. And again, he has the painters eye. Now like the eye which gives the figures wh. (which) [houses?] them with the flower & the barbed thorn marble pillar, & pen with light sees, There is no fear, but always [meriment?]. No [virtue?] that of light gives, rounds lit up but in great illuminated wid a vi

p.s: Still it is the world of

div.p: But still there is something anonymous about . He must stand out cannot confine his [characters?] in [huals?]: they are symbolic. He externalises: he embodies [learning?], not as a man, but gives it a [upaint?], a symbolic existence. Still The He shall pass away ignores himself, the first mind. The individual. He must and at the same time, forces are at work that are forcing the poet to be conscious of himself, as a separate individual; a man who he is giving something to the world: who asks something: but w who is conscious of the worlds scorn & neglect. Then is the artist thus aware of his birth as was not, nor , nor . He is becoming separate: outside; Not all his [illeg.] No longer a wandering voice, but specialised He is indeed more When he a When And here

He was then the first self conscious poet. The first real poet. And English poetry might have continued to be a book read aloud by the leisured in the great hall were had it not been for the other voice – the voice at the back door. Ironically [though?], when

himeself heard the voice of the mummers. He was present, it may be, at the pageant wh. (which) was acted before the at He saw the players dressed in green. He For time had made the peasant, probably the Earth in his own [guise?], a spectacle, a figure from the past. The old superstitions were so [harmless?] that the Q (Queen) was awed at their survival. But even while Spenser looked at their fantastic survival, with his the stage was being theatre was being built upon which the old English was the mummers were to act not Robin hood, not for the sophisticated antiquated pageantry to the a sophisticated audience, but , , the , ,
